questions.question: Identify the primary air pollutants among the following options: Carbon Monoxide (CO) Methane (CH4) Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2) Ozone (O3) Lead (Pb)
questions.explanation: affect human health, the environment, and the climate. They can be solid particles, liquid droplets, or gases. Air pollutants are typically categorised into: Primary Pollutants are emitted directly from a source into the atmosphere. Secondary Pollutants are not emitted directly. Instead, they form in the atmosphere through chemical reactions between primary pollutants and other atmospheric components. Primary Secondary Carbon Monoxide (CO) Sulfur Dioxide (SO I ) Nitrogen Oxides (NO I ) Particulate Matter (PM II , PM I . I ) Volatile Organic Compounds Lead (Pb) Ozone (O I ) Methane (CH4) Sulfates Nitrates Secondary Particulate Matter Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page. 860-863 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page.76

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indicator of air pollution?
questions.explanation: emitted from burning fossil fuels and industrial processes; causes respiratory problems and acid rain. Most important indicator of air pollution. Soiling Index Measures the accumulation of particulate matter (dirt) on surfaces. Specific amount of air is filtered through a filter paper and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter. Grit and Dust Measurement Quantifies the concentration of dust, grit deposits and small particulate matter present in the air. Coefficient of Haze Measures smoke and other aerosols in air. Air Pollution Index (API) Composite measure of overall air quality based on concentrations of various pollutants. McArdle's index is an indicator to measure: Air comfort. Predictable sweat rate in 4 hours. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page. 863 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page.77

questions.question: A patient resides in an area with an AQI of 250. What does it indicate?
questions.explanation: the quality of the air in a specific location . An indicator of air pollution. It is given by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) AQI doesn't measure Carbon Dioxide Components of Air Quality Index (AQI) Sulphur dioxide, Nitrogen dioxide, and Carbon monoxide levels Ozone level Particulate matter 2.5 and 10 Measures Lead, Ammonia, Chlorofluorocarbons, & Hydrogen sulphide levels etc. Central Pollution Control Board's Air Quality Standards: Air Quality Index (AQI) Category 0-50 Good 51-100 Satisfactory 101-200 Moderate 201-300 Poor 301-400 Very Poor 401-500 Severe/Hazardous Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page. 863 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page.77

questions.question: Match the following question Indoor Air Pollutants and their Sources: Pollutant Source 1. Polyaromatic hydrocarbons a. Destruction of construction materials 2. Asbestos b. Adhesives, Solvents and Aerosol sprays 3. Aldehydes c. Fuel consumption 4. Benzene d. Furnishings and Construction materials
questions.explanation: quality within enclosed spaces, typically caused by various pollutants and contaminants. These pollutants can originate from both indoor and outdoor sources and can significantly impact human health, comfort, and well-being. Source Pollutant Fuel consumption Carbon monoxide, Polyaromatic hydrocarbons, Nitrogen oxides Tobacco consumption Carbon monoxide, Polyaromatic hydrocarbons Coal combustion Sulphur oxides, arsenic, and fluorine Furnishings, construction materials, cooking Aldehydes Remodelling and destruction of construction materials Asbestos Remodelling/demolition of painted surfaces, leaded fuels, smelting Lead Building and construction materials Radon Adhesives, solvents, aerosol sprays, resin products Organic vapours like benzene, toluene Incineration, coal burning, petroleum burning Hydrocarbons Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page. 862,863 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page.76

questions.question: Which of the following is best measured by McArdle's Index?
questions.explanation: rate. McArdleâ€™s index: Measures air comfort and predictable 4 hours Sweat Rate (P4SR). P4SR classifies thermal comfort levels as: Comfort zone: 1 to 3 litres. Just tolerable: 3 to 4.5 litres. Intolerable: >4.5 litres. OTHER OPTIONS: Cooling Power of air (Option A) Determines the capacity of the atmosphere to dissipate the metabolite heat generated by humans. Includes 3 components: Air temperature, Air humidity and low air velocity. Measured by a Kata thermometer. Heat Stress Index (Option B) The ratio of evaporation required to maintain heat balance to maximum evaporation maintained in a particular environment is expressed as a percentage. Related to body sweating. It ranges from 0 to 100. Severe heat strain: 40 to 60 Very severe heat strain: 70 to 90 The upper limit of heat tolerance: 100. Effective Temperature Measures heat stress index. This includes air temperature, air humidity, and airflow/air velocity and cooling power of air Corrected effective temperature (Option D) A better indicator of air comfort than effective temperature. Includes 4 components: Air temperature, air humidity, air velocity, Mean radiant heat ( i.e Effective temperature+ mean radiant heat) A Globe thermometer is an instrument used to measure this. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine (27th edition) Page. IAPSM textbook of Community medicine (2nd edition) Page.

questions.question: What is the instrument's name, shown below, for measuring low air velocity?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B Explanation: Kata thermometer: Identification: It has a narrow and thin bulb that is red-coloured. Used to measure Low air velocity. Cooling power of air (rarely) as it does not provide reliable estimates. The cooling power of air is an indicator of air comfort. A dry Kata reading of more than 6 and a wet Kata reading of more than 20 indicate thermal comfort. Globe thermometer: Identification: A thick and wide bulb is present. Used to measure corrected effective temperature or radiant heat. Wet bulb hygrometer: Used to measure the relative humidity of the atmosphere. Anemometer: Used to measure air velocity in the early days.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the following device are not true? It measures radiant heat flux. It is used to assess thermal comfort in indoor environments. It measures a lower temperature than the ordinary air temperature It measures air temperature directly. It is not used to measure the cooling power of air.
questions.explanation: comfort in indoor environments represent the average temperature of the room surface, including radiant heat exchange. Air quality measurement Globe thermometer Thick, wide and hollow copper bulb coated with matt

questions.question: All of the following instruments can be used to measure air humidity except? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: velocity (wind speed), not air humidity. Air humidity measuring instruments Hygrometer Sling psychrometer 1. Wet and dry thermometers are mounted side by side Assman psychrometer 1. Can be used even in strong sunshine Dry and wet bulb hygrometer 1. Most widely used 2. Same readings in both (dry and wet) bulbs indicate 100 per cent saturation with moisture

questions.question: Which of the following is true about global warming?

options.A: It is primarily caused by increased solar radiation.
options.B: Paris Agreement aimed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in developed countries
options.C: Kyoto Protocol called for a 50% reduction in greenhouse emissions.
options.D: Water vapour is one of the important greenhouse gases.

questions.explanation: primarily due to human activities increasing greenhouse gases. (OPTION A) Important greenhouse gases: Water vapour, Carbon dioxide (mc), Nitrous oxide, Methane, Ground level ozone (OPTION D) Chlorofluorocarbons decrease the stratosphere ozone layer and enter harmful radiations released from the sun. Kyoto protocol: An initiative for climate protection and control of global warming 90% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions (Option C) Promote renewable energy sources Paris Agreement: To control greenhouse gas emissions and promote renewable energy sources. Improve air quality index. Aimed for both developing and developed nations (Option B) Reference: Parkâ€™s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 875

questions.question: Match the loudness of noise in decibels (dB) with their corresponding situation. 1. 60 dB a. Threshold of hearing damage 2. 85 dB b. Rupture of tympanic membrane 3. 160 dB c. Permanent deafness 4. 100 dB d. Normal conversation
questions.explanation: library 40 dB. 2. Normal conversatio n 60 to 65 dB. 3. Heavy street traffic 60 to 80 dB. 4. Tolerable daily exposure/ threshold to noise without hearing damage 85 dB. 5. Auditory fatigue 90 dB. 6. Permanent deafness (repeated or continuous exposure to noise) Around 100 dB 7. Boiler factories 120 dB. 8. Noise threshold for pain 140 dB. 9. Jet take-off 150 dB 10 . Rupture of tympanic membran e Above 160 dB. Reference: Parkâ€™s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th Edition Pg: 868-869

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a type of mechanical ventilation?
questions.explanation: Mechanical (Option A ) 1. Wind: Perflation : wind blows through a room Aspiration : wind bypasses and exerts a suction Cross-ventilation. 2. Diffusion : Air passes through small openings 3. Temperature Inequality : Air movement from high to low density due to temperature difference. 1. Exhaust : air is extracted outside by exhaust fans 2. Plenum : fresh air blown inside by centrifugal fans 3. Balanced : Combination of exhaust and plenum 4. Air conditioning: control of all air factors affecting physical and chemical conditions of the atmosphere

questions.question: Which of the following is a primary use of this instrument?

options.B: Measuring occupational noise exposure over a period of time
options.C: Measuring the intensity of sound in dB

questions.explanation: level meter. To measure noise exposure of a person over a period of time Eg: Occupational exposure 2. Audiometer (OPTION D) Used for evaluation of hearing ability 3. Hand-held microphone (OPTION C) To measure the intensity of sound in dB 4. Octave band analyser (OPTION A) To measure sound in octave bands Reflects sound spectrum ranging from low-pitched to high-pitched frequencies.

questions.question: Which of the following units is used to measure the luminous intensity of a light source?
questions.explanation: candela. PARAMETER DESCRIPTION UNIT OF MEASUREMENT Luminous intensity Brightness of a light source Candela Luminous flux Light flow Lumen (option A) Illumination/illuminance Measure of light reaching a surface Lux (option B) Brightness/luminance Measure of light reflected from a surface Lambert (option D) Daylight measure Intensity of daylight illumination Daylight factor Reference: Parkâ€™s textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th edition, page : 867

questions.question: Identify the correct statements regarding ideal housing standards. Built-up area of houses should not exceed 2/3rd in urban areas Roof of a house should be at least 10 meters in height Window area should be at least 1/5th of the floor area Cattle sheds should be at least 25 feet from the housing area Door and window should be at least 2/5th of the floor area
questions.explanation: from surroundings, pollution-free, not near mosquito-breeding sources Set Back: built-up area should not exceed 2/3rd in urban areas (statement 1) Floor: plinth height should be 2-3 ft; if mud, should be crack-free Walls: should use 9-inch bricks, low heat transmittance Roof: should be more than 10 ft, low heat transmittance (statement 2) Rooms: as per standards to avoid overcrowding Floor Area : living area: at least 100 sq. ft. for 1 person, 120 sq. ft for >1 person room: as per standards to avoid overcrowding Windows: at least 2 windows per room, height not more than 3 ft, should be I th of floor area (statement 3) , I th of the floor area with doors combined (statement 5) Lighting: Daylight factor >1% over half of the floor area Kitchen: well lit, dust & smoke-free, good water supply Privy: accessible, with water facilities Adequate waste disposal facilities Facilities for washing and bathing with proper water supply Rural: At least 2 living rooms The built-up area should not exceed 1/3rd in rural Windows: at least 10% of floor area Proper water, sanitation and waste disposal facilities Cattle sheds should be 25 feet away from housing areas (statement 4) Reference: Parkâ€™s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 878

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered overcrowding?

options.B: 1 person living in a floor space of 65 sq.ft.
options.C: 2 persons aged 7 of opposite gender in the same room
options.D: A child aged 8 years living in a floor space of 45 sq.ft.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 2 persons aged 7 of opposite gender in the same room Explanation: Overcrowding is considered when 2 persons of age 9 or more of the opposite gender, not husband and wife, live in the same room. Overcrowding: A situation where more people live in a space less than recommended can affect their physical (poor hygiene standards, spread of infections). psychosocial health (difficult sleep, inadequate privacy). Accepted standards: Persons Per Room Floor Space (1 sq.m. = 10 sq.ft.) 1 room - 2 persons 2 rooms - 3 persons 3 rooms - 5 persons (option A) 4 rooms - 7 persons 5 or more rooms - 10 persons (2 per each room) Not recommended: <50 sq.ft. Â½ person : 50-70 sq. ft. (option D) 1 person: 70-90 sq. ft. (option B) 1 Â½ persons: 90-100 sq. ft. 2 persons : >110 sq. ft. A baby <12 months of age are not counted as a person A child aged 1-10 years is counted as half a unit (option D) Reference: Parkâ€™s textbook of preventive and social medicine 27th edition, page : 879

questions.question: A 31-year-old male who wants to set up a radio diagnostic centre consults you regarding the possible health hazards his radio technicians might face. What is the ideal thickness of lead aprons you advise him to provide his employees that should prevent the employees from radiation hazards?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 0.5 mm Explanation: The ideal thickness of lead aprons to prevent the technicians from radiation hazards is 0.5 mm. Radiation exposure is hazardous (dose-dependent), ranging from acute radiation sickness up to genetic mutations, fetal anomalies and carcinogenesis. RADIATION DOSE BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS <5 rad No adverse effects 5-150 rad Nausea, vomiting Mild haematological changes 150-1100 rad Bone marrow failure (anaemia, infections, bleeding tendency - might require bone marrow transplantation), death occur in years. 1100-2000 rad Gastrointestinal destruction in addition (death almost always occurs in a few weeks) >2000 rad Muscle and brain damage (death occurs in days) Reference: Parkâ€™s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 871,872
